repnme.cdata!:
Mexico - First and Second Community
            Forestry Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the First Community Forestry
            Project for Mexico are as follows: outcome was moderately
            satisfactory; risk to the development outcome was moderate;
            Bank performance was satisfactory; and Borrower performance
            was also moderately satisfactory. Ratings for the Second
            Community Forestry Project for Mexico are as follows:
            outcome was satisfactory; risk to the development outcome
            was moderate; Bank performance was satisfactory; and
            Borrower performance was also satisfactory. Lessons learned
            include: improved stewardship of natural resources is
            probably the main contribution of community forestry in
            Mexico. Community forestry will not wipe out rural poverty
            in Mexico because the program is necessarily limited to
            communities with abundant forests and no land conflicts; and
            even in these communities incomes from forest activities
            will always make up only a small share of total incomes. Nor
            by itself will community forestry reverse the declining
            supply and lack of competitiveness of timber in Mexico. But
            it is an important part of the broader effort to protect the
            natural resource base. There are no quick fixes for building
            community capacity and institutional arrangements to manage
            and conserve forests. Plugging technical and infrastructure
            gaps is easy compared to the work of building trust in
            communities that have been ill served by Mexican governments
            for decades. The hefty contribution made by Procymaf
            communities to training and investment initiatives, the
            broad-based participation in land zoning exercises and the
            significant survival rate of the forest enterprises
            established by Procymaf is the best evidence yet that the
            programs are building capacity and sustainable institutional
            arrangements. It is important to embed support to individual
            communities within a broader framework that strengthens
            cooperation between communities and municipal and state
            governments and develops a network of professional expertise
            on forest-centered activities.

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey satisfactory project
            outcomes, a highly likely sustainability, and high
            institutional development impacts, in addition to
            satisfactory performances, both by the Bank and Borrower.
            Lessons concerning project design, suggest community
            forestry as an effective instrument for sustainable rural
            development, namely, this model encompassed the development
            of social capital (based on traditional forms of
            governance), a minimum base of natural capital (forest
            resources with commercial value), and, the development of
            technical and administrative capacity (human capital) of the
            producers. Hence, a regional vision on the use of natural
            resources should be fostered, seeking to achieve an economic
            scale, through greater integration of productive chains.
            However, the development of community forestry have not been
            linear, and the cause of structural limitation to access to
            markets, and lay natural capital, needs to be addressed, so
            as to access investment funds. While project design was not
            focused on communities engaged in land conflicts, (rather
            excluding significant numbers of communities, and depriving
            such communities from incentives to find a way out of
            conflict), the opposing decision however, could create a gap
            between communities engaged in conflict, and those that are
            not. Moreover, the project did not directly benefit the
            people living in, or near communities, that are not members,
            nor own the resources, or share in the decisions, neither in
            the form of employment and enhanced public services. This
            issue also raises questions about exacerbating gaps between
            richer and poorer, and leaving significant numbers of poor
            behind in the development process. Likewise, the project
            design did not directly assist women, or help them achieve
            an active role in community decision making. Project
            implementation lessons strongly support the frequent
            interventions of promoters, and technical support in forums,
            and other regional fora in community assemblies, including
            individual efforts to disseminate, and analyze options on
            performance of productive initiatives, which provided
            invaluable benefits in community strengthening. The
            viability of the community forestry enterprises, depend on
            their capacity to compete in global markets. However, the
            experience with private and parastatal companies has led to
            many communities with an understandable reluctance to engage
            in partnerships with the private sector. Hopefully, as
            communities strengthen their capacity for governance and
            technical skills, it will be possible to overcome this fear
            and establish linkages to private sector strategies, and to
            establish commercial alliances with productive agents,
            allowing access to new local, and regional markets.

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall objective of the Community
            Forestry Project is to support the implementation of key
            elements in the Government's redefined natural resource
            management strategy. Specific objectives are to: (1) improve
            natural resource management and conservation by community
            and ejido forestry resource owners; and (2) increase the
            range of forestry-based income generating options available
            to them. The project will have four components: (1)To assist
            Oaxaca's communities and ejidos (land grants for legal
            use and enjoyment that, prior to 1992 constitutional
            reforms, were state-owned and could not be sold) by
            financing activities, assistance, and training to prepare
            and update management plans for timber extraction; to
            prepare conservation plans for forested areas; to integrate
            resource management and forestry research; to develop
            silvicultural skills, and control fire and insects; to
            understand boundary conflict issues; to access credit,
            markets, and technologies; to increase the efficiency of
            forestry activities and enterprises, and to improve business
            and management, especially financial management skills. (2)
            To strengthen the capacity of Oaxaca's private service
            providers to assist communities and ejidos, and finance
            consultants and equipment needed to review and strengthen
            the government's certification and evaluation program
            for private sector providers. (3) To promote non-timber
            forest products in the six priority states with pine-oak
            forest by financing studies, grants, salaries, consultants,
            equipment, materials, and publications. (4) providing
            finance to strengthen state forestry institutions in five
            priority states with pine-oak forest.
